A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.

A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.
Does the concept of a/an Integral Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Noetherian ring to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Noetherian ring focuses on the properties of its ideals, specifically that every ascending chain of ideals stabilizes or that every ideal is finitely generated. This definition does not require the ring to be commutative, nor does it require the absence of zero divisors, which are the key characteristics of an integral domain.\n\nAn integral domain, by definition, is a commutative ring without zero divisors and is nonzero. These properties are not necessary for the definition of a Noetherian ring. A Noetherian ring can be non-commutative and can have zero divisors. Therefore, the concept of an integral domain is not necessary for the definition of a Noetherian ring to make sense.
